question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the standard enthalpy of solution of $\mathrm{AgCl}(\mathrm{s})$ in water from the enthalpies of formation of the solid and the aqueous ions.
llm_answer:
\[
\Delta_\mathrm{sol}H^\circ(\mathrm{AgCl(s)})=
\bigl[\Delta_\mathrm f^\circ(\mathrm{Ag^+(aq)})+
       \Delta_\mathrm f^\circ(\mathrm{Cl^-(aq)})\bigr]
-\Delta_\mathrm f^\circ(\mathrm{AgCl(s)})
\approx 5.3
\boxed{5.3}\; \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:
\[
\Delta_\mathrm{sol}H^\circ(\mathrm{AgCl(s)})=
\bigl[\Delta_\mathrm f^\circ(\mathrm{Ag^+(aq)})+
       \Delta_\mathrm f^\circ(\mathrm{Cl^-(aq)})\bigr]
-\Delta_\mathrm f^\circ(\mathrm{AgCl(s)})
\approx 5.3
\boxed{5.3}\; \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in chemical potential of a perfect gas when its pressure is increased isothermally from $1.8 \mathrm{~atm}$ to $29.5 \mathrm{~atm}$ at $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
For an ideal gas the chemical potential at a given temperature \(T\) varies with pressure as  

\[
\mu(T,P)=\mu^\circ (T)+RT\ln\!\frac{P}{P^\circ}
\]

Hence the change in chemical potential when the pressure changes from \(P_1\) to \(P_2\) at constant \(T\) is  

\[
\Delta\mu = \mu(T,P_2)-\mu(T,P_1)=RT\ln\!\frac{P_2}{P_1}
\]

Parameters  
\(T = 40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}=313.15\,\mathrm{K}\)  
\(R = 8.314\,\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}\,K^{-1}}\)  
\(P_1=1.8\,\mathrm{atm},\; P_2=29.5\,\mathrm{atm}\)

\[
\Delta\mu = (8.314\,\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(313.15\,\text{K})
           \ln\!\left(\frac{29.5}{1.8}\right)
\]

\[
\ln\!\left(\frac{29.5}{1.8}\right)=\ln(16.3889)\approx 2.7966
\]

\[
RT = 8.314 \times 313.15 \approx 2603.7\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\Delta\mu = 2603.7 \times 2.7966 \approx 7281 \;\text{J mol}^{-1}
          \approx 7.28\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{7.28}\,\mathrm{kJ}\,\mathrm{mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:
For an ideal gas the chemical potential at a given temperature \(T\) varies with pressure as  

\[
\mu(T,P)=\mu^\circ (T)+RT\ln\!\frac{P}{P^\circ}
\]

Hence the change in chemical potential when the pressure changes from \(P_1\) to \(P_2\) at constant \(T\) is  

\[
\Delta\mu = \mu(T,P_2)-\mu(T,P_1)=RT\ln\!\frac{P_2}{P_1}
\]

Parameters

\(P_1=1.8\,\mathrm{atm},\; P_2=29.5\,\mathrm{atm}\)

\[

           \ln\!\left(\frac{29.5}{1.8}\right)
\]

\[

\[
RT = 8.314 \times 313.15 \approx 2603.7\;\text{J mol}^{-1}

\[

          \approx 7.28\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{7.28}\,\mathrm{kJ}\,\mathrm{mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. For a van der Waals gas, $\pi_T=a / V_{\mathrm{m}}^2$. Calculate $\Delta U_{\mathrm{m}}$ for the isothermal expansion of nitrogen gas from an initial volume of $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^3$ to $24.8 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the molar entropy of a constant-volume sample of neon at $500 \mathrm{~K}$ given that it is $146.22 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
For a monatomic ideal gas the molar heat capacity at constant pressure is  

\[
c_{p}=\frac{5}{2}R=20.785\,\text{J\,K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1} .
\]

The change in entropy when the temperature changes from \(T_{1}=298 \text{ K}\) to \(T_{2}=500 \text{ K}\) is  

\[
\Delta S = \int_{T_{1}}^{T_{2}}\frac{c_{p}}{T}\,dT
          = c_{p}\,\ln\!\left(\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}\right)
          = 20.785\;\ln\!\left(\frac{500}{298}\right)
          \approx 10.76\;\text{J\,K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

Hence  

\[
S(500\,\text{K}) = S(298\,\text{K}) + \Delta S
                  = 146.22 + 10.76
                  \approx 156.98\,\text{J\,K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{157}\,\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}\,mol^{-1}}
\]
llm_output:

\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in entropy when $25 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy is transferred reversibly and isothermally as heat to a large block of iron at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
The reversible isothermal transfer of heat \(Q\) to a body at temperature \(T\) changes its entropy by  

\[
\Delta S_{\text{body}}=\frac{Q_{\text{rev}}}{T}.
\]

Here  

* \(Q_{\text{rev}}=+25\ \text{kJ}=2.50\times10^{4}\ \text{J}\) (heat added to the iron block),  
* \(T_{\text{iron}}=0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}=273.15\ \text{K}\).

Thus

\[
\Delta S_{\text{iron}}
   =\frac{2.50\times10^{4}\ \text{J}}{273.15\ \text{K}}
   \approx 9.16\times10^{1}\ \text{J\,K}^{-1}
   \;\;\approx\;\; 92\ \text{J\,K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{92}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

\[

\]

Here

\]

question: A gas at $250 \mathrm{~K}$ and $15 \mathrm{~atm}$ has a molar volume 12 per cent smaller than that calculated from the perfect gas law. Calculate the molar volume of the gas.
Calculate the mass of water vapour present in a room of volume $400 \mathrm{m}^3$ that contains air at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ on a day when the relative humidity is 60 percent.'

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The enthalpy of vaporization of chloroform $\left(\mathrm{CHCl}_3\right)$ is $29.4 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at its normal boiling point of $334.88 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the entropy of vaporization of chloroform at this temperature.
llm_answer:
The entropy change for vaporisation at the normal boiling point can be found from the Gibbs free‑energy relation at phase equilibrium:

\[
\Delta G^{\text{vap}} = \Delta H^{\text{vap}} - T\,\Delta S^{\text{vap}} = 0 
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\Delta S^{\text{vap}} = \frac{\Delta H^{\text{vap}}}{T}
\]

With  
\[
\Delta H^{\text{vap}} = 29.4\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}=29400\;\text{J mol}^{-1},
\qquad T = 334.88\;\text{K},
\]
we obtain

\[
\Delta S^{\text{vap}}=\frac{29400}{334.88}\approx 87.8\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{87.8}\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

\[

\]

\]

question: A gas at $250 \mathrm{~K}$ and $15 \mathrm{~atm}$ has a molar volume 12 per cent smaller than that calculated from the perfect gas law. Calculate the compression factor under these conditions.
llm_answer:
Because the actual molar volume \(V_{\text{real}}\) is 12 % smaller than the ideal value \(V_{\text{ideal}}\),

\[
V_{\text{real}} = (1-0.12)\,V_{\text{ideal}} = 0.88\,V_{\text{ideal}} .
\]

The compression factor is defined as

\[
Z=\frac{V_{\text{real}}}{V_{\text{ideal}}}=0.88 .
\]

\[
\boxed{0.88}
\]
llm_output:

\[
V_{\text{real}} = (1-0.12)\,V_{\text{ideal}} = 0.88\,V_{\text{ideal}} .
\]

The compression factor is defined as

\[
Z=\frac{V_{\text{real}}}{V_{\text{ideal}}}=0.88 .
\]

\[
\boxed{0.88}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Suppose that $3.0 \mathrm{mmol} \mathrm{N}_2$ (g) occupies $36 \mathrm{~cm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$ and expands to $60 \mathrm{~cm}^3$. Calculate $\Delta G$ for the process.
A vessel of volume $22.4 \mathrm{dm}^3$ contains $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_2$ and $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~N}_2$ at $273.15 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate their total pressure.
llm_answer:
The pressure of an ideal gas mixture is given by the ideal gas law  

\[
P = \frac{nRT}{V}
\]

**1. Total number of moles**

\[
n_{\text{total}} = n_{\mathrm{H_2}} + n_{\mathrm{N_2}}
                 = 2.0 \; \text{mol} + 1.0 \; \text{mol}
                 = 3.0 \; \text{mol}
\]

**2. Convert volume to liters**

\[
V = 22.4 \,\text{dm}^3 = 22.4 \,\text{L}
\]

**3. Use the ideal gas constant in \( \text{L}\,\text{atm}\,\text{K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1} \)**  

\(R = 0.082057\;\text{L atm K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\)

Temperature: \(T = 273.15\;\text{K}\)

**4. Compute the pressure**

\[
P = \frac{(3.0\;\text{mol}) (0.082057\;\text{L atm K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})
          (273.15\;\text{K})}{22.4\;\text{L}}
\]

First, \(0.082057 \times 273.15 \approx 22.414\;\text{L atm mol}^{-1}\).

Then, \(3.0 \times 22.414 = 67.242\;\text{L atm}\).

Finally,

\[
P = \frac{67.242\;\text{L atm}}{22.4\;\text{L}} \approx 3.00\;\text{atm}
\]

\[
\boxed{3}\,\mathrm{atm}
\]
llm_output:

\[

\]

\[

\[
\boxed{3}\,\mathrm{atm}

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an adiabatic reversible expansion.
llm_answer:
The expansion is adiabatic (no heat exchange) and reversible, so it is isentropic.  
For a reversible adiabatic process

\[
\Delta S_{\text{system}}=\int_{1}^{2}\frac{\delta Q_{\text{rev}}}{T}=0,
\]

and because \(\delta Q=0\), the surroundings also experience no entropy change. Therefore the total entropy change is

\[
\boxed{0}\;\text{J/K}
\]
llm_output:

For a reversible adiabatic process

\[
\Delta S_{\text{system}}=\int_{1}^{2}\frac{\delta Q_{\text{rev}}}{T}=0,
\]

and because \(\delta Q=0\), the surroundings also experience no entropy change. Therefore the total entropy change is

\[
\boxed{0}\;\text{J/K}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the Carnot efficiency of a modern steam turbine that operates with steam at $300^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and discharges at $80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. When a certain freon used in refrigeration was expanded adiabatically from an initial pressure of $32 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to a final pressure of $1.00 \mathrm{~atm}$, the temperature fell by $22 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the Joule-Thomson coefficient, $\mu$, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, assuming it remains constant over this temperature range.
llm_answer:
The Joule‑Thomson coefficient \(\mu\) is defined for an isenthalpic process as  

\[
\mu \equiv \left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial P}\right)_H .
\]

For a finite but small pressure change it can be approximated by  

\[
\mu \simeq \frac{\Delta T}{\Delta P},
\]

where \(\Delta T = T_f-T_i\) and \(\Delta P = P_f-P_i\).

**Given**

- Initial pressure \(P_i = 32 \text{ atm}\)  
- Final pressure \(P_f = 1.00 \text{ atm}\)  
- Initial temperature \(T_i = 0^\circ\text{C}=273.15\text{ K}\)  
- Final temperature \(T_f = 273.15\text{ K} - 22\text{ K}=251.15\text{ K}\)

**Calculate the changes**

\[
\Delta T = T_f - T_i = 251.15\text{ K}-273.15\text{ K} = -22\text{ K},
\]
\[
\Delta P = P_f - P_i = 1.00\text{ atm}-32\text{ atm} = -31\text{ atm}.
\]

**Joule‑Thomson coefficient**

\[
\mu = \frac{\Delta T}{\Delta P}
     = \frac{-22\text{ K}}{-31\text{ atm}}
     \approx 0.7097 \text{ K atm}^{-1}.
\]

Rounded to three significant figures,

\[
\boxed{0.710}\ \text{K atm}^{-1}.
\]
llm_output:

\[

\]

\]

Rounded to three significant figures,

\[
\boxed{0.710}\ \text{K atm}^{-1}.
\]

question:
Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The volume of a certain liquid varies with temperature as
$$
V=V^{\prime}\left\{0.75+3.9 \times 10^{-4}(T / \mathrm{K})+1.48 \times 10^{-6}(T / \mathrm{K})^2\right\}
$$
where $V^{\prime}$ is its volume at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate its expansion coefficient, $\alpha$, at $320 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
The thermal expansion coefficient is defined as  

\[
\alpha(T)=\frac{1}{V}\frac{dV}{dT}
\]

For  

\[
V=V'\!\left[\, 0.75+ aT+ bT^{2}\,\right],\qquad 
a=3.9\times10^{-4}\;{\rm K}^{-1},\; b=1.48\times10^{-6}\;{\rm K}^{-2}
\]

\[
\frac{dV}{dT}=V'\left(a+2bT\right)
\]

Hence  

\[
\alpha(T)=\frac{a+2bT}{0.75+aT+bT^{2}}
\]

At \(T=320\,{\rm K}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
aT &= 3.9\times10^{-4}\times 320=0.1248,\\[2pt]
bT^{2} &=1.48\times10^{-6}\times 320^{2}=0.151552,\\[2pt]
\text{denominator} &=0.75+0.1248+0.151552=1.026352.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
a+2bT =3.9\times10^{-4}+2\times1.48\times10^{-6}\times320
          =3.9\times10^{-4}+9.472\times10^{-4}
          =1.3372\times10^{-3}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\alpha(320\,{\rm K})=\frac{1.3372\times10^{-3}}{1.026352}
                    \approx 1.30\times10^{-3}\ {\rm K^{-1}}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.30\times10^{-3}}\ \text{K}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

\]

\[

a=3.9\times10^{-4}\;{\rm K}^{-1},\; b=1.48\times10^{-6}\;{\rm K}^{-2}
\]

\[
\frac{dV}{dT}=V'\left(a+2bT\right)
\]

Hence  

\[

\[

bT^{2} &=1.48\times10^{-6}\times 320^{2}=0.151552,\\[2pt]
\text{denominator} &=0.75+0.1248+0.151552=1.026352.

\[

\]

\[

\]

question: In an attempt to determine an accurate value of the gas constant, $R$, a student heated a container of volume $20.000 \mathrm{dm}^3$ filled with $0.25132 \mathrm{g}$ of helium gas to $500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and measured the pressure as $206.402 \mathrm{cm}$ of water in a manometer at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the value of $R$ from these data. (The density of water at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is $0.99707 \mathrm{g} \mathrm{cm}^{-3}$; a manometer consists of a U-shaped tube containing a liquid. One side is connected to the apparatus and the other is open to the atmosphere. The pressure inside the apparatus is then determined from the difference in heights of the liquid.)

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The standard enthalpy of combustion of solid phenol $\left(\mathrm{C}_6 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{OH}\right)$ is $-3054 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}_{\text {and }}$ its standard molar entropy is $144.0 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the standard Gibbs energy of formation of phenol at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
The standard Gibbs energy of formation \(\Delta G_{\mathrm f}^\circ\) can be obtained from the standard enthalpy of formation \(\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ\) and the standard entropy \(S^\circ\):

\[
\Delta G_{\mathrm f}^\circ = \Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ - T\,S^\circ
\]

---

### 1.  Find \(\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ\) of phenol

For the standard combustion of phenol

\[
\mathrm{C_6H_5OH(s)} + 7\,\mathrm{O_2(g)} \rightarrow 6\,\mathrm{CO_2(g)} + 3\,\mathrm{H_2O(l)}
\]

\[
\Delta H_{\text{comb}}^\circ = \sum n\,\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\text{products}) -
\sum n\,\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\text{reactants})
\]

The standard enthalpies of formation at \(298.15\ \mathrm{K}\) are  

\[
\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2(g)}) = -393.509\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
\[
\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O(l)}) = -285.830\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
\[
\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\mathrm{O_2(g)}) = 0
\]

Hence

\[
\Delta H_{\text{comb}}^\circ
= \bigl[6(-393.509)+3(-285.830)\bigr]
-\bigl[\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH})+7\cdot 0\bigr]
\]

\[
-3054~\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
= -2361.054~\text{kJ} - 857.49~\text{kJ}
- \Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH})
\]

\[
\Delta H_{\mathrm f}^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH})
= -3218.544~\text{kJ} + 3054~\text{kJ}
= -164.544~\text{kJ\,mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the Carnot efficiency of a primitive steam engine operating on steam at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and discharging at $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
The Carnot efficiency of a heat engine operating between a hot reservoir at \(T_{h}\) and a cold reservoir at \(T_{c}\) is  

\[
\eta_{\text{Carnot}}=1-\frac{T_{c}}{T_{h}} .
\]

For the steam engine,
\[
T_{h}=100^{\circ}\text{C}=100+273.15=373.15\ \text{K},
\qquad
T_{c}=60^{\circ}\text{C}=60+273.15=333.15\ \text{K}.
\]

Thus

\[
\eta_{\text{Carnot}}
=1-\frac{333.15}{373.15}
=1-\frac{40}{373.15}
=\frac{40}{373.15}\approx 0.107.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.107}
\]
llm_output:

=1-\frac{40}{373.15}
=\frac{40}{373.15}\approx 0.107.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.107}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the maximum non-expansion work per mole that may be obtained from a fuel cell in which the chemical reaction is the combustion of methane at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
The maximum non‑expansion work obtainable from a fuel cell is equal to the negative of the Gibbs free‑energy change of the overall reaction at 298 K.

For the combustion of methane the balanced reaction is  

\[
\mathrm{CH_4(g)} + 2\,\mathrm{O_2(g)} \;\longrightarrow\; \mathrm{CO_2(g)} + 2\,\mathrm{H_2O(l)} .
\]

Using standard Gibbs‑free‑energy of formation values at 298 K  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{CH_4}) &= -50.8 \;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2}) &= -394.4 \;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O(l)}) &= -237.1 \;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The Gibbs free‑energy change of the reaction is  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^\circ_{\mathrm{rxn}}
&=\Bigl[\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2})
      +2\,\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O(l)})\Bigr]
     -\Bigl[\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{CH_4})+2\,\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{O_2})\Bigr] \\
&= \bigl[-394.4+2(-237.1)\bigr] - \bigl[-50.8+0\bigr] \\
&= -868.6 - (-50.8) \\
&= -817.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence the maximum non‑expansion (electric) work per mole obtainable is

\[
W_{\text{max}} = -\Delta G^\circ_{\mathrm{rxn}}
= 817.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\approx \boxed{818}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in Gibbs energy of $35 \mathrm{~g}$ of ethanol (mass density $0.789 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ ) when the pressure is increased isothermally from $1 \mathrm{~atm}$ to $3000 \mathrm{~atm}$.
Calculate the pressure exerted by $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{Xe}$ when it is confined to $1.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
The ideal‑gas law gives the pressure:

\[
PV=nRT
\]

where  
\(n = 1.0\;\text{mol}\) (Xe),  
\(V = 1.0\;\text{dm}^3 = 1.0\;\text{L}\),  
\(T = 25^{\circ}\!C = 25+273.15 = 298\;\text{K}\),  
\(R = 0.082057\;\text{L·atm·mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\).

Insert the values:

\[
P = \frac{(1.0\;\text{mol})(0.082057\;\text{L·atm·mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298\;\text{K})}{1.0\;\text{L}}
      = 24.5\;\text{atm}
\]

Hence the pressure exerted by the xenon gas is  

\[
\boxed{24.5}\;\text{atm}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an isothermal reversible expansion.
llm_answer:
The entropy change for a reversible isothermal expansion of an ideal gas is  

\[
\Delta S = n R \ln\!\left(\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}}\right)
          = n R \ln \frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}
\]

Here the volume doubles, so \(V_{2}/V_{1}=2\) and the pressure halves:
\(P_{2}=P_{1}/2\).

Number of moles of \( \mathrm{N_2}\):

\[
n=\frac{m}{M}= \frac{14\;\text{g}}{28\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}=0.50\;\text{mol}
\]

Using \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\):

\[
\Delta S = (0.50\;\text{mol})(8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})\ln 2
          \approx 4.157\;\text{J K}^{-1}\times 0.693147
          \approx 2.88\;\text{J K}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{2.88}\;\text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta H$ when two copper blocks, each of mass $10.0 \mathrm{~kg}$, one at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and the other at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, are placed in contact in an isolated container. The specific heat capacity of copper is $0.385 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}$ and may be assumed constant over the temperature range involved.
llm_answer:
When the two identical copper blocks reach equilibrium the final temperature is the simple average of the initial temperatures,

\[
T_{\text{final}}=\frac{100^\circ\text{C}+0^\circ\text{C}}{2}=50^\circ\text{C}.
\]

The enthalpy change of each block is

\[
\Delta H_i = m\,c\,\Delta T
= (10.0\,\text{kg})(1000\,\text{g\,kg}^{-1})\,\bigl(0.385\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{K g}}\bigr)\,\Delta T .
\]

For the block initially at \(100^\circ\text{C}\):

\[
\Delta T = 50-100 = -50\ \text{K},
\]
\[
\Delta H_1 = 10\,000\,\text{g}\times 0.385\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{K g}}\times (-50\ \text{K})
= -1.925\times 10^5\,\text{J}.
\]

For the block initially at \(0^\circ\text{C}\):

\[
\Delta T = 50-0 = +50\ \text{K},
\]
\[
\Delta H_2 = 10\,000\,\text{g}\times 0.385\,\frac{\text{J}}{\text{K g}}\times (+50\ \text{K})
= +1.925\times 10^5\,\text{J}.
\]

The total enthalpy change of the isolated system is the sum,

\[
\Delta H_{\text{total}} = \Delta H_1 + \Delta H_2
= (-1.925\times 10^5) + ( +1.925\times 10^5) = 0\ \text{J}.
\]

\[
\boxed{0}\ \text{J}
\]
llm_output:

question: A perfect gas undergoes isothermal compression, which reduces its volume by $2.20 \mathrm{dm}^3$. The final pressure and volume of the gas are $5.04 \mathrm{bar}$ and $4.65 \mathrm{dm}^3$, respectively. Calculate the original pressure of the gas in atm.
llm_answer:
The gas follows the ideal gas relation for an isothermal process:  

\[
\frac{P_1 V_1}{P_2 V_2}=1 \qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
P_1 = P_2\,\frac{V_2}{V_1}
\]

The initial volume is  

\[
V_1 = V_2 + \Delta V = 4.65\,\text{dm}^3 + 2.20\,\text{dm}^3 = 6.85\,\text{dm}^3
\]

Hence  

\[
P_1 = 5.04 \, \frac{4.65}{6.85}\;\text{bar}
       = 3.4213 \;\text{bar}
\]

Convert bar to atm (\(1\;\text{bar}=0.986923\;\text{atm}\)):

\[
P_1 = 3.4213 \times 0.986923 = 3.3766 \;\text{atm}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures:

\[
\boxed{3.38}\;\text{atm}
\]

\]

\boxed{11.4}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta S$ (for the system) when the state of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of perfect gas atoms, for which $C_{p, \mathrm{~m}}=\frac{5}{2} R$, is changed from $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1.00 atm to $125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $5.00 \mathrm{~atm}$.
llm_answer:
The entropy change of an ideal gas for a reversible change from \((T_1,\,P_1)\) to \((T_2,\,P_2)\) is

\[
\Delta S_{\text{system}} = n\Bigl(C_{p,m}\,\ln\frac{T_2}{T_1}-R\,\ln\frac{P_2}{P_1}\Bigr).
\]

Here \(n = 3.00\;\text{mol}\), \(Cp,m} = \dfrac{5}{2}R\), \(R = 8.314\;\text{J\,mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\),  
\(T_1 = 298.15\;\text{K}\), \(T_2 = 398.15\;\text{K}\), \(P_1 = 1.00\;\text{atm}\), \(P_2 = 5.00\;\text{atm}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ln\frac{T_2}{T_1} &= \ln\!\left(\frac{398.15}{298.15}\right)\approx 0.288,\\
\ln\frac{P_2}{P_1} &= \ln(5)\approx 1.609.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta S_{\text{system}}
&= 3.00\Bigl[\frac{5}{2}R\, (0.288)-R\, (1.609)\Bigr] \\
&= 3.00\, R\,\bigl(0.72-1.609\bigr) \\
&= 3.00\, R\,(-0.889) \\
&= -2.667\,R \\
&= -2.667(8.314)\;\text{J\,K}^{-1}\\
&\approx -22.2\;\text{J\,K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{-22.2}\;\text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A chemical reaction takes place in a container of cross-sectional area $100 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. As a result of the reaction, a piston is pushed out through $10 \mathrm{~cm}$ against an external pressure of $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$. Calculate the work done by the system.
llm_answer:
The piston moves a distance \(10 \text{ cm}=0.10\text{ m}\) with a cross‑sectional area \(100\text{ cm}^2=0.01\text{ m}^2\).  
The volume change is

\[

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. When $229 \mathrm{~J}$ of energy is supplied as heat to $3.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{Ar}(\mathrm{g})$ at constant pressure, the temperature of the sample increases by $2.55 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the molar heat capacities at constant pressure of the gas.
llm_answer:
The molar heat capacity at constant pressure is obtained from

\[
C_p=\frac{dQ}{n\,dT}.
\]

Here  

- \(dQ = 229\ \text{J}\) (heat supplied),  
- \(n = 3.0\ \text{mol}\) (amount of argon),  
- \(dT = 2.55\ \text{K}\) (temperature rise).

So

\[
C_p = \frac{229\ \text{J}}{(3.0\ \text{mol})(2.55\ \text{K})}
     = \frac{229\ \text{J}}{7.65\ \text{mol·K}}
     \approx 29.9\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{29.9}\,\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The change in the Gibbs energy of a certain constant-pressure process was found to fit the expression $\Delta G / \text{J}=-85.40+36.5(T / \text{K})$. Calculate the value of $\Delta S$ for the process.
llm_answer:
The Gibbs free‑energy change is given by  

\[
\Delta G(T)= -85.40 \;\text{J} + 36.5\,T \quad(\text{J/K}\cdot T)
\]

For any process at constant pressure, the temperature dependence of the Gibbs energy is

\[
\left(\frac{\partial \Delta G}{\partial T}\right)_P = -\,\Delta S
\]

Thus

\[
-\Delta S = \frac{d\Delta G}{dT}= 36.5 \;\text{J\,K}^{-1}
\]

so that

\[
\Delta S = -36.5 \;\text{J\,K}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-36.5}\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta S_\text{tot}$ when two copper blocks, each of mass $10.0 \mathrm{~kg}$, one at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and the other at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, are placed in contact in an isolated container. The specific heat capacity of copper is $0.385 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}$ and may be assumed constant over the temperature range involved.
llm_answer:
The two copper blocks exchange heat until thermal equilibrium at  

\[
T_f=\frac{T_{\text{hot}}+T_{\text{cold}}}{2}=\frac{373.15\,\text{K}+273.15\,\text{K}}{2}=323.15\,\text{K}.
\]

---

### 1.  Heat transfer

For each block  
\(m = 10.0\;\text{kg}=1.0\times10^{4}\;\text{g}\)   and   \(c = 0.385\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{g}^{-1}\).

\[
Q_{\text{hot}} = mc\,(T_f-T_{\text{hot}})
                = (1.0\times10^{4})(0.385)\,(323.15-373.15)
                =-1.925\times10^{5}\;\text{J},
\]
\[
Q_{\text{cold}} = - Q_{\text{hot}}
                = +1.925\times10^{5}\;\text{J}.
\]

---

### 2.  Entropy change of each block

\[
\Delta S_{\text{hot}}
  = mc\ln\!\left(\frac{T_f}{T_{\text{hot}}}\right)
  = (1.0\times10^{4})(0.385)\,
    \ln\!\left(\frac{323.15}{373.15}\right)
  \approx -5.52\times10^{2}\;\text{J K}^{-1},
\]

\[
\Delta S_{\text{cold}}
  = mc\ln\!\left(\frac{T_f}{T_{\text{cold}}}\right)
  = (1.0\times10^{4})(0.385)\,
    \ln\!\left(\frac{323.15}{273.15}\right)
  \approx 6.49\times10^{2}\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

---

### 3.  Total entropy change

\[
\Delta S_{\text{tot}}
 = \Delta S_{\text{hot}}+\Delta S_{\text{cold}}
 \approx (-5.52\times10^{2})+ (6.49\times10^{2})
 \approx 9.6\times10^{1}\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{9.6\times10^{1}}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The standard enthalpy of formation of ethylbenzene is $-12.5 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate its standard enthalpy of combustion.
llm_answer:
The combustion of ethylbenzene is  

\[
\ce{C8H10 + 10.5 O2 -> 8 CO2 + 5 H2O}
\]

Using standard enthalpies of formation (in kJ mol\(^{-1}\)):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{C8H10}) &= -12.5,\\
\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{CO2}) &= -393.5,\\
\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{H2O(l)}) &= -285.83.
\end{aligned}
\]

The enthalpy of reaction:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H_{\text{comb}} &= \sum \nu_{\text{products}}\Delta H_f^\circ
 - \sum \nu_{\text{reactants}}\Delta H_f^\circ\\[4pt]
&= \bigl[\,8(-393.5)+5(-285.83)\,\bigr]
  -\bigl[\,(-12.5)+0\,\bigr] \\[4pt]
&= (-4577.15)-(-12.5)\\
&= -4564.65\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Rounded to the nearest integer:

\[
\boxed{-4565}\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the final pressure of a sample of carbon dioxide that expands reversibly and adiabatically from $57.4 \mathrm{kPa}$ and $1.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ to a final volume of $2.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$. Take $\gamma=1.4$.
llm_answer:
For a reversible adiabatic expansion of an ideal gas  

\[
PV^{\gamma}=\text{constant}
\]

where \(\gamma=C_p/C_v\).

Thus  

\[
P_{\text f}=P_{\text i}\left(\frac{V_i}{V_f}\right)^{\gamma}
\]

Substituting the given values:

\[
P_{\text f}=57.4\,\text{kPa}\left(\frac{1.0\,\text{dm}^3}{2.0\,\text{dm}^3}\right)^{1.4}
           =57.4\,\text{kPa}\,(0.5)^{1.4}
\]

\[
(0.5)^{1.4}=e^{\,1.4\ln 0.5}\approx e^{-0.9704}\approx 0.379
\]

\[
P_{\text f}\approx 57.4\times 0.379 \approx 21.8\;\text{kPa}
\]

\[
\boxed{21.8}\text{ kPa} \]

The excess Gibbs energy of a real gas relative to an ideal gas at the same \(T\) and \(P\) is  

\[
\Delta G_{\text{real-ideal}} = RT\ln\phi ,
\]

\[
\Delta G = (8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(200\;\text{K})\ln(0.72)
          = 1662.8\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\times (-0.3285)
          \approx -546\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
          = -0.546\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-0.546}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\]

So

\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} H^{\ominus}= -1373\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}+4.96\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}

\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.013 25 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $w$.
llm_answer:
The work done on or by a gas is given by the integral

\[
w=\int_{V_{i}}^{V_{f}} -P_{\text{ext}}\; dV .
\]

In this case the sample occupies a fixed volume of \(15.0\;\text{dm}^{3}\); hence \(V_{\text{f}}=V_{\text{i}}\) and

\[
dV=0.
\]

Consequently the integral vanishes:

\[
w = \int_{V_i}^{V_f} -P_{\text{ext}}\; dV = 0 .
\]

Thus, regardless of the van der Waals description of \( \mathrm{CO}_{2} \), the work associated with the temperature change at constant volume is

\[
\boxed{0\;\text{J}} .
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta S$.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $\Delta S$.
llm_answer:
The entropy change of the gas is 

\[
\Delta S = nC_{V,\,m}\ln\!\frac{T_f}{T_i}+nR\ln\!\frac{V_f}{V_i}
\]

where  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta U &= -P_{\text{ext}}\Delta V =-101325\;\text{Pa}\times 2.0\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^3
          =-20.27\;\text{J} \\
\Delta T &= \frac{\Delta U}{n C_{V,\,m}}
         =\frac{-20.27}{2\times28.8}
         =-3.52\times10^{-1}\;\text{K} \\
T_f &= 298.15-0.352=297.80\;\text{K} \\
V_i &= \frac{nRT_i}{P_i}
     =\frac{2\times8.314\times298.15}{1.01325\times10^6}=4.8896\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^3 \\
V_f &= V_i+\Delta V
     =4.8896\times10^{-3}+2.0\times10^{-4}=5.0896\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^3 \\
\ln\frac{T_f}{T_i}&=\ln(0.99883)=-0.001171, \qquad
\ln\frac{V_f}{V_i}=\ln(1.04036)=0.039604 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus

\[
\Delta S = 2(28.8)(-0.001171)+2(8.314)(0.039604)
          =-0.0675+0.6581
          =0.5906\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

Rounded to the appropriate significant figures:  

\[
\boxed{0.59}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the compression factor from the virial expansion of the van der Waals equation.
llm_answer:
Using the virial form of the van der Waals equation  

\[
Z \;=\; 1+\frac{P}{RT}\;\Bigl(b-\frac{a}{RT}\Bigr)
\]

with  

* \(P = 327.6\ \text{atm}\)  
* \(T = 776.4\ \text{K}\)  
* \(a = 5.464\ \text{dm}^6\,\text{atm}\,\text{mol}^{-2}\)  
* \(b = 0.03049\ \text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}\)  
* \(R = 0.082057\ \text{atm}\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}\,\text{K}^{-1}\)

1. Calculate \(RT\):

\[
RT = (0.082057)\,(776.4) = 63.71\ \text{atm}\,\text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

2. Evaluate \(b - \frac{a}{RT}\):

\[
\frac{a}{RT} = \frac{5.464}{63.71}=0.08573\ \text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]
\[
b-\frac{a}{RT}=0.03049-0.08573=-0.05524\ \text{dm}^3\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

3. Multiply by \(P/RT\):

\[
\frac{P}{RT}=\frac{327.6}{63.71}=5.142
\]
\[
\frac{P}{RT}\Bigl(b-\frac{a}{RT}\Bigr)=5.142(-0.05524)=-0.2840
\]

4. Obtain the compression factor:

\[
Z = 1-0.2840 = 0.716
\]

\[
\boxed{0.716}
\]

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the compression factor from the data.
llm_answer:
The compression factor \(Z\) is defined by  

\[
Z=\frac{p\,V_m}{RT}
\]

where  
\(V_m\) is the molar volume, \(p\) the pressure, \(R\) the ideal‑gas constant, and
\(T\) the temperature.

1. **Determine molar volume \(V_m\)**  

\[
V_m=\frac{M}{\rho}
\]

\(M=18.02\;\text{g mol}^{-1}=0.01802\;\text{kg mol}^{-1}\),  
\(\rho=133.2\;\text{kg m}^{-3}\).

\[
V_m=\frac{0.01802}{133.2}\,\text{m}^{3}\text{mol}^{-1}
      \approx1.353\times10^{-4}\,\text{m}^{3}\text{mol}^{-1}
      =0.1353\,\text{dm}^{3}\text{mol}^{-1}
      =0.1353\,\text{L mol}^{-1}
\]

2. **Insert the data**  

\[
p = 327.6\;\text{atm}, \qquad
T = 776.4\;\text{K}, \qquad
R = 0.082057\;\frac{\text{L atm}}{\text{mol K}}
\]

\[
Z = \frac{(327.6\;\text{atm})(0.1353\;\text{L mol}^{-1})}
         {(0.082057\;\text{L atm mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(776.4\;\text{K})}
\]

3. **Compute**  

\[
Z = \frac{44.32}{63.71}\approx 0.696
\]

\[
\boxed{0.696}
\]

question: A certain gas obeys the van der Waals equation with $a=0.50 \mathrm{~m}^6 \mathrm{~Pa}$ $\mathrm{mol}^{-2}$. Its volume is found to be $5.00 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $273 \mathrm{~K}$ and $3.0 \mathrm{MPa}$. From this information calculate the van der Waals constant $b$. What is the compression factor for this gas at the prevailing temperature and pressure?

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta H$.
llm_answer:
The enthalpy change for an ideal gas depends only on temperature:

\[
\Delta H = n\,C_{H,\mathrm{m}}\,\Delta T
\]

For a diatomic ideal gas  
\[
C_{H,\mathrm{m}} = C_{V,\mathrm{m}} + R
                 = 27.5\,\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1} + 8.314\,\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
                 = 35.814\,\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

Given  
\(n = 3.00\ \text{mol}\)  
\(\Delta T = 250\ \text{K} - 200\ \text{K} = 50\ \text{K}\)

\[
\Delta H = 3.00 \times 35.814 \times 50
        = 3.00 \times 1790.7
        = 5372.1\ \text{J}
        = 5.37\ \text{kJ}
\]

\[
\boxed{5.37}\,\text{kJ}
\]

\]

question: Use the van der Waals parameters for chlorine to calculate approximate values of the Boyle temperature of chlorine.
llm_answer:
The Boyle temperature \(T_{\text B}\) for a van der Waals gas is obtained from the condition that the second virial coefficient vanishes:

\[
B(T) = b-\frac{a}{RT}=0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
T_{\text B}= \frac{a}{bR}
\]

For chlorine the van der Waals constants are \(a=5.3\text{ L}^2\text{ atm mol}^{-2}\) and \(b=7.6\times10^{-2}\text{ L mol}^{-1}\) (values taken from standard tables).  
Using \(R=0.082057\text{ L atm mol}^{-1}\text{ K}^{-1}\),

\[
T_{\text B}= \frac{5.3}{(7.6\times10^{-2})(0.082057)}
          \approx 8.7\times10^{2}\ \text{K}
\]

Hence the Boyle temperature of chlorine is

\[
\boxed{870}\text{ K}
\]

\]

\]

A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $\Delta U$.
llm_answer:
\[
\Delta U = q + w
\]

- Heat supplied to the gas: \(q = +2.35 \,\text{kJ}\)  
- The gas is contained in a fixed‑volume vessel, therefore the work done by the system is

\[
w = -\int P_{\text{ext}}\;dV = 0 .
\]

Hence

\[
\Delta U = q = 2.35 \,\text{kJ}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.35}\text{ kJ}
\]

question: Suppose the concentration of a solute decays exponentially along the length of a container. Calculate the thermodynamic force on the solute at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ given that the concentration falls to half its value in $10 \mathrm{~cm}$.
llm_answer:
The chemical potential of the solute is  

\[
\mu=\mu^{\circ}+RT\ln c .
\]

The thermodynamic driving force (per mole) is the negative gradient of \(\mu\):

\[
f = -\frac{d\mu}{dx}= -RT\,\frac{1}{c}\frac{dc}{dx}.
\]

For an exponential decay  
\(c(x)=c_0 e^{-kx}\),  

\[
\frac{dc}{dx}=-kc, \qquad 
\frac{1}{c}\frac{dc}{dx}=-k .
\]

Hence  

\[
f = RT\,k .
\]

---

**Find \(k\).**  
The concentration falls to half in \(10\,\text{cm}\):

\[
\frac{1}{2}=e^{-k(10\ \text{cm})}\;\Longrightarrow\;k=\frac{\ln 2}{10\ \text{cm}}
           =0.0693147\ \text{cm}^{-1}
           =6.93147\ \text{m}^{-1}.
\]

---

**Compute \(RT\).**  
At \(25^{\circ}\text{C}\) (\(T=298\ \text{K}\)),

\[
RT=8.314\ \frac{\text{J}}{\text{mol K}}\times298\ \text{K}=2477\ \frac{\text{J}}{\text{mol}}
    =2477\ \frac{\text{N\,m}}{\text{mol}} .
\]

---

**Force**

\[
f = RT\,k = 2477\ \frac{\text{N\,m}}{\text{mol}}\times 6.93147\ \text{m}^{-1}
      = 17156\ \frac{\text{N}}{\text{mol}}
      \approx 17.2\ \frac{\text{kN}}{\text{mol}} .
\]

\[
\boxed{17.2}\ \text{kN mol}^{-1}
\]

question: A container is divided into two equal compartments. One contains $3.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_2(\mathrm{~g})$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$; the other contains $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~N}_2(\mathrm{~g})$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the Gibbs energy of mixing when the partition is removed. Assume perfect behaviour.
llm_answer:
The Gibbs energy change on mixing follows the ideal‑gas expression  

\[
\Delta G_{\text{mix}}
   = nRT \sum_i y_i \ln y_i ,
\]

where \(y_i\) are the final mole fractions of the components.

**Mole fractions**

\[
y_{\text{H}_2}=\frac{3.0}{3.0+1.0}=0.75,\qquad
y_{\text{N}_2}=\frac{1.0}{3.0+1.0}=0.25
\]

**Numerical calculation**

\[
n=4.0\ \text{mol},\qquad
R=8.314\ \frac{\text{J}}{\text{mol·K}},\qquad
T=298.15\ \text{K}
\]

\[
\sum_i y_i \ln y_i
 = 0.75\ln(0.75)+0.25\ln(0.25)
 = -0.5623
\]

\[
\Delta G_{\text{mix}}
 = (4.0)(8.314)(298.15)(-0.5623)
 \approx -5.58\times10^3\ \text{J}
 =-5.58\ \text{kJ}
\]

\[
\boxed{-5.58}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: Caesium (m.p. $29^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, b.p. $686^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) was introduced into a container and heated to $500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. When a hole of diameter $0.50 \mathrm{~mm}$ was opened in the container for $100 \mathrm{~s}$, a mass loss of $385 \mathrm{mg}$ was measured. Calculate the vapour pressure of liquid caesium at $500 \mathrm{~K}$.
Calculate the typical wavelength of neutrons that have reached thermal equilibrium with their surroundings at $373 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
The de Broglie wavelength of a neutron in thermal equilibrium is  

\[
\lambda=\frac{h}{\sqrt{3m_{\!n}k_{\mathrm B}T}},
\]

where  

* \(h=6.62607015\times10^{-34}\,\text{J\,s}\)  
* \(m_{\!n}=1.674927471\times10^{-27}\,\text{kg}\) (neutron mass)  
* \(k_{\mathrm B}=1.380649\times10^{-23}\,\text{J\,K}^{-1}\)  
* \(T=373\,\text{K}\).

---

**Step‑by‑step calculation**

1. Compute the thermal kinetic energy factor  
   \[
   3m_{\!n}k_{\mathrm B}T
   =3(1.674927471\times10^{-27}\,\text{kg})
     (1.380649\times10^{-23}\,\text{J\,K}^{-1})

question: Calculate the separation of the $\{123\}$ planes of an orthorhombic unit cell with $a=0.82 \mathrm{~nm}, b=0.94 \mathrm{~nm}$, and $c=0.75 \mathrm{~nm}$.

Calculate the moment of inertia of an $\mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}$ molecule around the axis defined by the bisector of the $\mathrm{HOH}$ angle (3). The $\mathrm{HOH}$ bond angle is $104.5^{\circ}$ and the bond length is $95.7 \mathrm{pm}$.

The data below show the temperature variation of the equilibrium constant of the reaction $\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{CO}_3(\mathrm{~s}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{s})+\mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$. Calculate the standard reaction enthalpy of the decomposition.
$\begin{array}{lllll}T / \mathrm{K} & 350 & 400 & 450 & 500 \\ K & 3.98 \times 10^{-4} & 1.41 \times 10^{-2} & 1.86 \times 10^{-1} & 1.48\end{array}$
llm_answer:
The van 't Hoff equation for the temperature dependence of an equilibrium constant is  

\[
\ln K=\frac{-\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}\,\frac1T+\frac{\Delta S^{\circ}}R ,
\]

so that the slope of the plot \(\ln K\) versus \(1/T\) equals \(-\Delta H^{\circ}/R\).

Using the data:

| \(T\) (K) | \(K\) | \(\ln K\) | \(1/T\) (K\(^{-1}\)) |
|-----------|--------|-----------|---------------------|
| 350 | \(3.98\times10^{-4}\) | \(-7.82906\) | 0.00285714 |
| 400 | \(1.41\times10^{-2}\) | \(-4.26162\) | 0.00250000 |
| 450 | \(1.86\times10^{-1}\) | \(-1.68183\) | 0.00222222 |
| 500 | \(1.48\) | \(0.39207\) | 0.00200000 |

The slope \(m\) of \(\ln K\) vs \(1/T\) is obtained from two extreme points (or from a linear regression):

\[
m=\frac{\ln K_{500}-\ln K_{350}}{1/T_{500}-1/T_{350}}
 =\frac{0.39207-(-7.82906)}{0.00200000-0.00285714}
 \approx-9.57\times10^{3}\ \text{K}.
\]

Hence

\[
\Delta H^{\circ}= -m\,R = (9.57\times10^{3})(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})
 \approx 7.96\times10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}
 \approx 79.6\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{79.6}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

llm_answer:
For a diatomic molecule the vibrational angular frequency is  

\[
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{k}{\mu}},
\]

where \(k\) is the force constant and \(\mu\) is the reduced mass.  
For \({}^{35}\mathrm{Cl}_2\)

\[
\mu=\frac{m_{35}\,m_{35}}{m_{35}+m_{35}}
     =\frac{m_{35}}{2},
\qquad
m_{35}=35\,u=35(1.66054\times10^{-27}\text{ kg})=5.8169\times10^{-26}\text{ kg}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\mu=\frac{5.8169\times10^{-26}}{2}=2.9085\times10^{-26}\text{ kg}.
\]

---

### 1.  Angular frequency

\[
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{319\ \text{N/m}}{2.9085\times10^{-26}\text{ kg}}}
        =\sqrt{1.096\times10^{28}\ \text{s}^{-2}}
        =1.05\times10^{14}\ \text{rad/s}.
\]

### 2.  Linear frequency

\[
\nu=\frac{\omega}{2\pi}
      =\frac{1.05\times10^{14}}{6.283}
      =1.67\times10^{13}\ \text{Hz}.
\]

### 3.  Wavenumber (cm\(^{-1}\))

\[
\tilde\nu=\frac{\nu}{c}
        =\frac{1.67\times10^{13}\ \text{Hz}}
               {2.9979\times10^{10}\ \text{cm/s}}
        \approx5.56\times10^{2}\ \text{cm}^{-1}.
\]

\[

V(x)=D \beta^2 x^2+\cdots

\[
V(x)\simeq D\,\beta^{2}x^{2}\;\;=\;\;\frac12 kx^{2}

\]

k=2(7.31\times10^{-19}\,\text{J})(3.2761\times10^{20}\,\text{m}^{-2})
  =2(239.5\,\text{N\,m}^{-1})\approx4.79\times10^{2}\,\text{N\,m}^{-1}.
\]

question: Using the Bohr theory, calculate the ionization energy (in electron volts and in $\mathrm{kJ} \cdot \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ ) of singly ionized helium.
llm_answer:
The ionization energy of a hydrogen‑like ion is  

\[
E_{\text{ion}} = R_{\infty} \, Z^2
\]

where \(R_{\infty}=13.605693\,\text{eV}\) is the Rydberg energy and \(Z\) is the nuclear charge.

For singly ionised helium (\(\mathrm{He}^{+}\)), \(Z = 2\):

\[
E_{\text{ion}} = 13.605693\;\text{eV}\times 2^2
               = 13.605693\times 4
               = 54.422772\;\text{eV}\approx 54.42\;\text{eV}
\]

Converting to \( \text{kJ}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\) using \(1\,\text{eV}=96.485\,\text{kJ}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\):

\[
E_{\text{ion}} = 54.422772\;\text{eV}\times 96.485
                \approx 5.25\times 10^3\;\text{kJ}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{54.42}\ \text{eV}
\]

question: A proton and a negatively charged $\mu$ meson (called a muon) can form a short-lived species called a mesonic atom. The charge of a muon is the same as that on an electron and the mass of a muon is $207 m_{\mathrm{e}}$. Assume that the Bohr theory can be applied to such a mesonic atom and calculate the frequency associated with the $n=1$ to $n=2$ transition in a mesonic atom.
llm_answer:
The energy levels of a hydrogen‐like atom with reduced mass \(\mu\) are  

\[
E_n=-\,\frac{\mu c^{2}\,\alpha^{2}}{2n^{2}} .
\]

For a muonic hydrogen atom (\(Z=1\)) the relevant reduced mass is  

\[
\mu=\frac{m_{p}\,m_{\mu}}{m_{p}+m_{\mu}}
      \approx \frac{1836.15\,m_{e}\;\times 206.77\,m_{e}}
              {1836.15\,m_{e}+206.77\,m_{e}}
      \approx 186.0\,m_{e}\;,
\]
so \(\mu\approx1.7\times10^{-28}\ {\rm kg}\).

The transition frequency for \(n=1\rightarrow 2\) is  

\[
\nu_{1\to 2}=\frac{E_{1}-E_{2}}{h}
             =\frac{\mu c^{2}\alpha^{2}}{2h}
               \Bigl(1-\frac{1}{4}\Bigr)
             =\frac{3}{8}\,\frac{\mu c^{2}\alpha^{2}}{h}.
\]

Using  

\[
c=2.99792458\times10^{8}\ {\rm m\,s^{-1}},\qquad
\alpha=1/137.035999,\qquad 
h=6.62607015\times10^{-34}\ {\rm J\,s},
\]

we obtain  

\[
\nu_{1\to 2}
   \approx\frac{3}{8}\,
           \frac{(1.7\times10^{-28}\ {\rm kg})\,(2.9979\times10^{8}\ {\rm m\,s^{-1}})^{2}\,
             (5.33\times10^{-5})}{6.6261\times10^{-34}}
   \approx 4.6\times10^{17}\ {\rm Hz}.
\]

Hence, expressed in the requested unit,

\[
\boxed{4.6}\ 10^{17}\ \text{Hz}.

question: Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of an electron traveling at $1.00 \%$ of the speed of light.

To a good approximation, the microwave spectrum of $\mathrm{H}^{35} \mathrm{Cl}$ consists of a series of equally spaced lines, separated by $6.26 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~Hz}$. Calculate the bond length of $\mathrm{H}^{35} \mathrm{Cl}$.
llm_answer:
The rotational constants for a rigid diatomic molecule are related to the line spacing by  

\[
\Delta\nu = 2B,\qquad B=\frac{h}{8\pi^2 I},
\]

where \(I\) is the moment of inertia.  
Given the spacing  

\[
\Delta\nu = 6.26\times10^{11}\ \text{Hz},
\]
we find  

\[
B=\frac{\Delta\nu}{2}=3.13\times10^{11}\ \text{Hz}.
\]

The moment of inertia is

\[
I=\frac{h}{8\pi^2 B}=\frac{6.626\times10^{-34}\ \text{J s}}
{8\pi^2\,(3.13\times10^{11}\ \text{Hz})}
   \approx 2.68\times10^{-47}\ \text{kg\,m}^2 .
\]

For H\(_{35}\)Cl the reduced mass is

\[
\mu=\frac{m_{\rm H}\, m_{\rm Cl}}
{m_{\rm H}+m_{\rm Cl}}
      \approx \frac{(1.0078\,u)(34.9689\,u)}{1.0078\,u+34.9689\,u}
      \approx 1.63\times10^{-27}\ \text{kg}.
\]

The bond length \(r\) follows from \(I=\mu r^2\):

\[
r=\sqrt{\frac{I}{\mu}}\approx
\sqrt{\frac{2.68\times10^{-47}}
             {1.63\times10^{-27}}}\;
           \text{m}
        \approx 1.28\times10^{-10}\ \text{m}
        \approx 1.28\ \text{Å}
        \approx 128\ \text{pm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{128}\ \text{pm}
\]

question: Calculate the probability that a particle in a one-dimensional box of length $a$ is found between 0 and $a / 2$.
llm_answer:
The stationary wavefunctions for a particle in an infinite potential well of length \(a\) are  

\[
\psi_n(x)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}}\sin\!\left(\frac{n\pi x}{a}\right) ,
\qquad n=1,2,3,\dots
\]

The probability density is  

\[
|\psi_n(x)|^2=\frac{2}{a}\sin^2\!\left(\frac{n\pi x}{a}\right).
\]

The probability \(P\) of finding the particle between \(x=0\) and \(x=a/2\) is  

\[
\begin{aligned}
P &= \int_{0}^{a/2} |\psi_n(x)|^2\,dx
   = \frac{2}{a}\int_{0}^{a/2}\sin^2\!\left(\frac{n\pi x}{a}\right)\,dx \\[4pt]
  &= \frac{2}{a}\int_{0}^{a/2}\frac{1-\cos\!\bigl(2n\pi x/a\bigr)}{2}\,dx \\[4pt]
  &= \frac{1}{a}\int_{0}^{a/2}\Bigl[1-\cos\!\bigl(2n\pi x/a\bigr)\Bigr]\,dx.
\end{aligned}
\]

Integrating,

\[
\begin{aligned}
P &= \frac{1}{a}\Biggl[ x - \frac{a}{2n\pi}\sin\!\Bigl(\frac{2n\pi x}{a}\Bigr)\Biggr]_{0}^{\,a/2} \\
  &= \frac{1}{a}\left(\frac{a}{2} - 0\right) = \frac{1}{2},
\end{aligned}
\]
since \(\sin(n\pi)=0\) for integer \(n\).

Thus, irrespective of the quantum number \(n\), the probability of finding the particle in the left half of the box is

\[
\boxed{\tfrac{1}{2}}.
\]

question: Radiation from an X-ray source consists of two components of wavelengths $154.433 \mathrm{pm}$ and $154.051 \mathrm{pm}$. Calculate the difference in glancing angles $(2 \theta)$ of the diffraction lines arising from the two components in a diffraction pattern from planes of separation $77.8 \mathrm{pm}$.

A chemical reaction takes place in a container of cross-sectional area $50 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. As a result of the reaction, a piston is pushed out through $15 \mathrm{~cm}$ against an external pressure of $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$. Calculate the work done by the system.
llm_answer:
The work done by the system is  

\[
W=P\,\Delta V=P\,A\,d
\]

where  

\(P = 1~\text{atm}=1.013\times10^{5}\,\text{Pa}\) (external pressure)  
\(A = 50~\text{cm}^{2}=5.0\times10^{-3}\,\text{m}^{2}\) (cross‑sectional area)  
\(d = 15~\text{cm}=0.15~\text{m}\) (piston displacement).

Thus  

\[
\Delta V = A\,d = (5.0\times10^{-3}\,\text{m}^{2})(0.15~\text{m})=7.5\times10^{-4}\,\text{m}^{3}
\]

\[
W = (1.013\times10^{5}\,\text{Pa})(7.5\times10^{-4}\,\text{m}^{3})
     \approx 7.6\times10^{1}\,\text{J}
\]

Rounded to two significant figures:

\[
\boxed{76}\ \text{J}
\]

question: Calculate the change in Gibbs energy of $35 \mathrm{~g}$ of ethanol (mass density $0.789 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ ) when the pressure is increased isothermally from 1 atm to 3000 atm.
llm_answer:
\[
\Delta G
= \int_{P_1}^{P_2} V\,dP
= V\,(P_2-P_1)
\]

Mass of ethanol \(m = 35\;\text{g}\), density \(\rho = 0.789\;\text{g\,cm}^{-3}\)

\[
V = \frac{m}{\rho}
  = \frac{35}{0.789}\;\text{cm}^3
  \approx 44.34\;\text{cm}^3
  = 4.434\times10^{-5}\;\text{m}^3
\]

Pressure change \( \Delta P = (3000-1)\,\text{atm}
= 2999\,\text{atm}
= 2999(1.01325\times10^5)\;\text{Pa}
\approx 3.0387\times10^8\;\text{Pa}\)

\[
\Delta G = (4.434\times10^{-5}\,\text{m}^3)(3.0387\times10^8\,\text{Pa})
        \approx 1.347\times10^4\;\text{J}
        \approx 13.5\;\text{kJ}
\]

\[
\boxed{13.5}\;\text{kJ}
\]

question: The promotion of an electron from the valence band into the conduction band in pure $\mathrm{TIO}_2$ by light absorption requires a wavelength of less than $350 \mathrm{~nm}$. Calculate the energy gap in electronvolts between the valence and conduction bands.

Suppose that the normalized wavefunction for an electron in a carbon nanotube of length $L=10.0 \mathrm{~nm}$ is: $\psi=(2 / L)^{1 / 2} \sin (\pi x / L)$. Calculate the probability that the electron is between $x=4.95 \mathrm{~nm}$ and $5.05 \mathrm{~nm}$.
llm_answer:
\[
P=\int_{4.95\,\text{nm}}^{5.05\,\text{nm}}\!\left|\psi(x)\right|^{2}dx
=\frac2{L}\int_{4.95}^{5.05}\sin^{2}\!\left(\frac{\pi x}{L}\right)dx
\]

Using \(\sin^{2}\theta=\frac12[1-\cos(2\theta)]\) and \(L=10\,\text{nm}\):

\[
P=\frac{1}{L}\left[x-\frac{L}{2\pi}\sin\!\left(\frac{2\pi x}{L}\right)\right]_{4.95}^{5.05}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
P&=\frac1{10}\Bigl[(5.05-4.95)-\frac{10}{2\pi}\bigl(\sin(1.01\pi)-\sin(0.99\pi)\bigr)\Bigr]\\
&=\frac1{10}\Bigl[0.10-\frac{5}{\pi}\bigl(-0.03141-0.03141\bigr)\Bigr]\\[4pt]
&=\frac1{10}\left[0.10- \frac{5}{\pi}(-0.06282)\right]\\[4pt]
&=0.02 .
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.020}\]

question: A sample of the sugar D-ribose of mass $0.727 \mathrm{~g}$ was placed in a calorimeter and then ignited in the presence of excess oxygen. The temperature rose by $0.910 \mathrm{~K}$. In a separate experiment in the same calorimeter, the combustion of $0.825 \mathrm{~g}$ of benzoic acid, for which the internal energy of combustion is $-3251 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, gave a temperature rise of $1.940 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the enthalpy of formation of D-ribose.

Calculate the molar energy required to reverse the direction of an $\mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}$ molecule located $100 \mathrm{pm}$ from a $\mathrm{Li}^{+}$ ion. Take the magnitude of the dipole moment of water as $1.85 \mathrm{D}$.
llm_answer:
To reverse the dipole of the water molecule 180° relative to the electric field of the \( \mathrm{Li}^{+}\) ion the change in potential energy is

\[
\Delta U = 2\, pE
\]

where \(p\) is the dipole moment and \(E\) is the electric field magnitude at the water’s position.

---

**Step 1 – Electric field of the ion**

\[
E = \frac{1}{4\pi \varepsilon_0}\frac{q}{r^{2}}
      = k\,\frac{e}{r^{2}}
\]

with  
\(k = 8.98755\times10^{9}\;\mathrm{N\,m^{2}\,C^{-2}}\),  
\(e = 1.60218\times10^{-19}\;\mathrm{C}\),  
\(r = 100\;\mathrm{pm}=1.0\times10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m}\).

\[
E = \frac{8.98755\times10^{9}\; \times 1.60218\times10^{-19}}
        {(1.0\times10^{-10})^{2}}
   \approx 1.44\times10^{11}\;\mathrm{V\,m^{-1}}
\]

---

**Step 2 – Dipole moment**

\[
p = 1.85\;\mathrm{D}=1.85 \times 3.33564\times10^{-30}
  \;\mathrm{C\,m}\approx 6.17\times10^{-30}\;\mathrm{C\,m}
\]

---

**Step 3 – Energy change per molecule**

\[
\Delta U_{\text{molecule}} = 2\,pE
   \approx 2 \times 6.17\times10^{-30}\times1.44\times10^{11}
   \approx 1.78\times10^{-18}\;\mathrm{J}
\]

---

**Step 4 – Convert to molar energy**

\[
\Delta U_{\text{mol}} = \Delta U_{\text{molecule}}\; N_A
   \approx 1.78\times10^{-18}\;\mathrm{J}\times
          6.022\times10^{23}\;\mathrm{mol^{-1}}
   \approx 1.07\times10^{6}\;\mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}}
\]

\[
\Delta U_{\text{mol}} \approx 1.07\times10^{3}\;\mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{1.07}\quad 10^{3}\;\mathrm{kJ}\,\mathrm{mol^{-1}}
\]

question: Suppose that the junction between two semiconductors can be represented by a barrier of height $2.0 \mathrm{eV}$ and length $100 \mathrm{pm}$. Calculate the transmission probability of an electron with energy $1.5 \mathrm{eV}$.
llm_answer:
The transmission coefficient for a rectangular barrier of height \(V_{0}\) and width \(a\) (with \(E<V_{0}\)) is  

\[
T=\frac{1}{1+\displaystyle\frac{V_{0}^{2}\sinh ^{2}(\kappa a)}{4\,E\,(V_{0}-E)}} ,
\qquad 
\kappa=\frac{\sqrt{2m(V_{0}-E)}}{\hbar}.
\]

---

**1.  Compute \(\kappa\)**  

\[
V_{0}-E=0.5\;\mathrm{eV}=0.5(1.602\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J})=8.01\times10^{-20}\,\mathrm{J}.
\]

\[
\kappa=\frac{\sqrt{2m(V_{0}-E)}}{\hbar}
       =\frac{\sqrt{\,2(9.11\times10^{-31}\,\mathrm{kg})(8.01\times10^{-20}\,\mathrm{J})\,}}
              {1.055\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\,s}}
       \approx 3.6\times10^{9}\;\mathrm{m^{-1}} .
\]

---

**2.  Evaluate \(\sinh(\kappa a)\)**  

Barrier width: \(a=100\,\mathrm{pm}=1.0\times10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m}\).

\[
\kappa a\approx (3.6\times10^{9})(1.0\times10^{-10})\approx 0.36 .
\]

\[
\sinh(\kappa a)=\sinh(0.36)\approx 0.37 .
\]

---

**3.  Compute the transmission probability**

\[
T=\frac{1}{1+\dfrac{V_{0}^{2}\sinh ^{2}(\kappa a)}{4\,E\,(V_{0}-E)}}
  =\frac{1}{1+\dfrac{(2\;\mathrm{eV})^{2}(0.37)^{2}}{4(1.5\;\mathrm{eV})(0.5\;\mathrm{eV})}}
  =\frac{1}{1+0.182}\approx 0.85 .
\]

\[
\boxed{T\approx 0.85}
\]

Thus about \(85\%\) of the electrons with \(1.5\;\mathrm{eV}\) will tunnel through the 2 eV, 100 pm barrier.

question: The equilibrium pressure of $\mathrm{O}_2$ over solid silver and silver oxide, $\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O}$, at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ is $11.85 \mathrm{~Pa}$. Calculate the standard Gibbs energy of formation of $\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{s})$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
The reaction at equilibrium is

\[
\mathrm{Ag}_2\mathrm O(s)\;\rightleftharpoons\;2\,\mathrm{Ag}(s)+\tfrac12\,\mathrm{O}_2(g)
\]

At equilibrium \( \Delta G = 0 \), so

\[
\Delta G^\circ_{\text{decomp}} + RT\ln Q = 0
\]

With \(Q = (P_{\mathrm{O}_2})^{1/2}\) and \(P_{\mathrm{O}_2}=11.85~\text{Pa}=1.185\times10^{-4}\,\text{bar}\),

\[
\Delta G^\circ_{\text{decomp}} = -\,\frac{RT}{2}\ln P_{\mathrm{O}_2}
      = -\,\frac{(8.314\,\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298\,\text{K})}{2}
         \ln(1.185\times10^{-4})
\]

\[
\Delta G^\circ_{\text{decomp}}
  = -\,1238.8\,\text{J mol}^{-1}\times(-9.0413)
  = +1.120\times10^{4}\,\text{J mol}^{-1}
\]

The formation reaction is the reverse of decomposition, so

\[
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{Ag}_2\mathrm O) = -\Delta G^\circ_{\text{decomp}}
   = -1.120\times10^{4}\,\text{J mol}^{-1}
   = -11.20\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-11.20}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: The NOF molecule is an asymmetric rotor with rotational constants $3.1752 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}, 0.3951 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$, and $0.3505 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$. Calculate the rotational partition function of the molecule at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
The rotational partition function for an asymmetric top is approximated at high temperature by  

\[
Q_{\text{rot}}\;=\;\frac{(2\pi kT)^{3/2}}{\sigma h^{3}}\,
\sqrt{I_{a} I_{b} I_{c}}
\]

where  
\(I_{a}= \dfrac{h}{8\pi^{2}cA}\),  
\(I_{b}= \dfrac{h}{8\pi^{2}cB}\),  
\(I_{c}= \dfrac{h}{8\pi^{2}cC}\)  
and \(\sigma=1\) for NOF (no symmetry axis).

**1.  Moments of inertia (SI units)**  

\[
\begin{aligned}
A &=3.1752\,{\rm cm^{-1}}\;\;\Rightarrow\;A=317.52\,{\rm m^{-1}} \\
B &=0.3951\,{\rm cm^{-1}}\;\;\Rightarrow\;B=39.51\,{\rm m^{-1}}  \\
C &=0.3505\,{\rm cm^{-1}}\;\;\Rightarrow\;C=35.05\,{\rm m^{-1}}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
F=\frac{h}{8\pi^{2}c}=2.8024\times10^{-44}\;{\rm kg\,m^{2}}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
I_{a}&=\frac{F}{A}=8.83\times10^{-47}\;{\rm kg\,m^{2}}\\
I_{b}&=\frac{F}{B}=7.09\times10^{-46}\;{\rm kg\,m^{2}}\\
I_{c}&=\frac{F}{C}=8.00\times10^{-46}\;{\rm kg\,m^{2}}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\sqrt{I_{a}I_{b}I_{c}}=7.09\times10^{-69}\;{\rm kg\,m^{2}}
\]

**2.  Temperature factor**

\[
kT =1.380649\times10^{-23}\,\text{J}\times298.15\;\text{K}
      =4.114\times10^{-21}\,\text{J}
\]

\[
(2\pi kT)^{3/2}=4.16\times10^{-30}\,\text{J}^{3/2}
\]

**3.  Rotational partition function**

\[
h^{3}=(6.62607015\times10^{-34}\,\text{J\,s})^{3}=2.912\times10^{-100}\,\text{J}^{3}\text{s}^{3}
\]

\[
Q_{\text{rot}}=
\frac{4.16\times10^{-30}}{2.912\times10^{-100}}\,
(7.09\times10^{-69})
=1.01\times10^{2}
\]

Thus

\[
Q_{\text{rot}}\approx 1.01\times10^{2}\;=\;0.101\times10^{3}\;.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.101}\;10^{3}
\]

where

Q_{\text{rot}}\approx 1.01\times10^{2}\;=\;0.101\times10^{3}\;.

question: Calculate the standard potential of the $\mathrm{Ce}^{4+} / \mathrm{Ce}$ couple from the values for the $\mathrm{Ce}^{3+} / \mathrm{Ce}$ and $\mathrm{Ce}^{4+} / \mathrm{Ce}^{3+}$ couples.
llm_answer:
The overall standard potential for the four‑electron reduction

\[
\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}+4e^{–}\rightarrow \mathrm{Ce}
\]

follows from the free‑energy additivity of the two one‑ and three‑electron
steps

\[
\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}+e^{-}\rightarrow \mathrm{Ce}^{3+}\qquad   
\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}+3e^{-}\rightarrow \mathrm{Ce}.
\]

Because \(\Delta G = -n\,F\,E\), the total free energy change is

\[
\Delta G_{\text{tot}} = -F\bigl[\,E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}/\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}}
+3\,E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}/\mathrm{Ce}}\,\bigr]
     =-4F\,E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}/\mathrm{Ce}} .
\]

Hence

\[
E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}/\mathrm{Ce}}
   =\frac{E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}/\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}}
          +3\,E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}/\mathrm{Ce}}}{4}\;.
\]

\[
\boxed{E^\circ_{\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}/\mathrm{Ce}}
      =\dfrac{E^\circ_{\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}/\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}}
          +3\,E^\circ_{\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}/\mathrm{Ce}}}{4}} \,V
\]
llm_output:

\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}+3e^{-}\rightarrow \mathrm{Ce}.
\]

Because \(\Delta G = -n\,F\,E\), the total free energy change is

\[
\Delta G_{\text{tot}} = -F\bigl[\,E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}/\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}}
+3\,E_{\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}/\mathrm{Ce}}\,\bigr]

\]

          +3\,E^\circ_{\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}/\mathrm{Ce}}}{4}} \,V
\]

question: When ultraviolet radiation of wavelength $58.4 \mathrm{~nm}$ from a helium lamp is directed on to a sample of krypton, electrons are ejected with a speed of $1.59 \times 10^6 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$. Calculate the ionization energy of krypton.

Calculate $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} G^{\ominus}(375 \mathrm{~K})$ for the reaction $2 \mathrm{CO}(\mathrm{g})+\mathrm{O}_2(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$ from the values of $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} G^{\ominus}(298 \mathrm{~K})$ : and $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} H^{\ominus}(298 \mathrm{~K})$, and the GibbsHelmholtz equation.
llm_answer:
**Solution**

The Gibbs‑Helmholtz equation relates the temperature dependence of the standard Gibbs energy:

\[
\frac{\Delta G^{\circ}}{T}= \frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{T}-\Delta S^{\circ}
\]

Assuming that \(\Delta H^{\circ}\) is essentially constant between 298 K and 375 K, we can eliminate \(\Delta S^{\circ}\) using the 298 K data.  
At 298 K

\[
\Delta S^{\circ}= \frac{\Delta H^{\circ}_{298}-\Delta G^{\circ}_{298}}{298}
\]

Insert this into the Gibbs–Helmholtz expression and evaluate at \(T=375\) K:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^{\circ}_{375}
&= \Delta H^{\circ}_{298} - 375\,\Delta S^{\circ}          \\[4pt]
&= \Delta H^{\circ}_{298}\left(1-\frac{375}{298}\right)
     + \frac{375}{298}\,\Delta G^{\circ}_{298}
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 1.  Standard thermodynamic data (kJ mol\(^{-1}\))

| Species | \(\Delta_f G^{\circ}\) | \(\Delta_f H^{\circ}\) |
|---------|------------------------|------------------------|
| CO(g)   | –137.16                | –110.5                 |
| O\(_2\)(g) | 0                     | 0                      |
| CO\(_2\)(g) | –394.36                | –393.5                 |

For the reaction  
\(2\,\text{CO} (g) + \text{O}_2 (g) \rightarrow 2\,\text{CO}_2 (g)\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^{\circ}_{298}
  &= 2(-394.36) - [2(-137.16)+0]
  = -788.72 + 274.32
  = -514.4 \ \text{kJ\,mol}^{-1}.\\[4pt]
\Delta H^{\circ}_{298}
  &= 2(-393.5) - [2(-110.5)+0]
  = -787.0 + 221.0
  = -566.0 \ \text{kJ\,mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 2.  Evaluate at 375 K

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^{\circ}_{375}
&= (-566.0)\left(1-\frac{375}{298}\right)
   + \frac{375}{298}(-514.4)\\[4pt]
&= (-566.0)(-0.257715)
   + 1.257715(-514.4)\\[4pt]
&= 145.8
   - 646.5\\[4pt]
&= -500.7\ \text{kJ\,mol}^{-1}\approx -5.01\times10^2\ \text{kJ\,mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{-501}\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

question: The vapour pressure of benzene is $53.3 \mathrm{kPa}$ at $60.6^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, but it fell to $51.5 \mathrm{kPa}$ when $19.0 \mathrm{~g}$ of an non-volatile organic compound was dissolved in $500 \mathrm{~g}$ of benzene. Calculate the molar mass of the compound.
llm_answer:
The decrease in vapour pressure is due to the presence of a non‑volatile solute.  
For a dilute solution,

\[
P_{\text{soln}}=x_{\text{benzene}}\;P_{\text{0}}, \qquad 
x_{\text{benzene}}=\frac{n_{\text{benzene}}}{n_{\text{benzene}}+n_{\text{solute}}}
\]

Given  
\(P_{0}=53.3\,\text{kPa}\), \(P_{\text{soln}}=51.5\,\text{kPa}\)

\[
x_{\text{benzene}}=\frac{51.5}{53.3}=0.9662
\]

Hence  

\[
x_{\text{solute}}=1-x_{\text{benzene}}=0.0338
\]

Moles of benzene in \(500\,\text{g}\):

\[
n_{\text{benzene}}=\frac{500\;\text{g}}{78.11\;\text{g\,mol}^{-1}}=6.401\;\text{mol}
\]

Let \(M\) be the molar mass of the solute.  
Moles of solute:

\[
n_{\text{solute}}=x_{\text{solute}}\,(n_{\text{benzene}}+n_{\text{solute}})
\;\Longrightarrow\;
n_{\text{solute}}=\frac{x_{\text{solute}}}{1-x_{\text{solute}}}\,n_{\text{benzene}}
= \frac{0.0338}{0.9662}\,6.401
=2.24\times10^{-1}\;\text{mol}
\]

Mass of solute = \(19.0\,\text{g}\).  
Therefore

\[
M=\frac{19.0\;\text{g}}{2.24\times10^{-1}\;\text{mol}}
\approx 8.5\times10^{1}\;\text{g\,mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{85}\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

An electron confined to a metallic nanoparticle is modelled as a particle in a one-dimensional box of length $L$. If the electron is in the state $n=1$, calculate the probability of finding it in the following regions: $0 \leq x \leq \frac{1}{2} L$.
llm_answer:
\[
P=\int_{0}^{L/2}\!\!\left|\psi_1(x)\right|^2dx
  =\int_{0}^{L/2}\frac{2}{L}\sin^2\!\left(\frac{\pi x}{L}\right)dx
  =\frac{2}{L}\left[\frac{x}{2}-\frac{\sin(2\pi x/L)}{4\pi/L}\right]_{0}^{L/2}
  =\frac12 .
\]

\[
\boxed{\tfrac12}
\]

question: A swimmer enters a gloomier world (in one sense) on diving to greater depths. Given that the mean molar absorption coefficient of seawater in the visible region is $6.2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$, calculate the depth at which a diver will experience half the surface intensity of light.
llm_answer:
The intensity \(I\) of light that reaches a depth \(d\) in a medium obeys Beer–Lambert’s law

\[
I=I_0\,\exp(-\alpha\,c\,d),
\]

where  
* \(\alpha\) is the mean molar absorption coefficient,  
* \(c\) is the concentration of the absorbing material,  
* \(d\) is the depth.

The diver experiences a half‑intensity when

\[
\frac{I}{I_0}=\frac12 =\exp(-\alpha\,c\,d)\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
\alpha\,c\,d=\ln 2 .
\]

---

### 1.  Concentration of dissolved salts in seawater  

Standard seawater has a salinity of \(\text{S}=35\;\text{g}\,\text{salt}\,\,\text{kg}^{-1}\).
The molar mass of seawater’s dominant salt (NaCl) is \(M_{\text{NaCl}}\approx58.44\;
\text{g mol}^{-1}\).

\[
c=\frac{\text{mass of salt per liter}}{M_{\text{NaCl}}}
   =\frac{35\;\text{g}\,\text{kg}^{-1}\times 1.025\;\text{kg L}^{-1}}
          {58.44\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}
   \approx 0.615\;\text{mol L}^{-1}
   =0.615\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}.
\]

---

### 2.  Solve for the depth  

\[
d=\frac{\ln 2}{\alpha\,c}
  =\frac{0.6931}{(6.2\times10^{-3}\,\text{dm}^3\text{mol}^{-1}\text{cm}^{-1})(0.615\;\text{mol dm}^{-3})}
  =\frac{0.6931}{3.81\times10^{-3}\;\text{cm}^{-1}}
  \approx 1.82\times10^{2}\;\text{cm}
  =1.82\;\text{m}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.8}\ \text{m}
\]

question: The vibrational wavenumber of $\mathrm{Br}_2$ is $323.2 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$. By evaluating the vibrational partition function explicitly (without approximation), at what temperature is the value within 5 per cent of the value calculated from the approximate formula?
llm_answer:
The vibrational partition function of a harmonic oscillator is  

\[
q_{\text{vib}}=\frac{1}{1-e^{-x}}, \qquad x=\frac{h\nu}{k_{\text{B}}T}.
\]

The approximate (classical) formula is  

\[
q_{\text{approx}}=\frac{k_{\text{B}}T}{h\nu}=\frac{1}{x}.
\]

We need the temperature where the two values differ by **5 %**, i.e.

\[
\left|\frac{q_{\text{vib}}-q_{\text{approx}}}{q_{\text{approx}}}\right|=0.05
\Longrightarrow
\frac{x}{1-e^{-x}}-1=0.05 .
\]

Solving \(x/(1-e^{-x})=1.05\) gives \(x\approx 0.0986\).

The vibrational frequency is related to the given wavenumber \(\tilde{\nu}=323.2\:\text{cm}^{-1}\):

\[
h\nu = h c\,\tilde{\nu}
      = (6.62607015\times10^{-34}\,\text{J\,s})(2.99792458\times10^{10}\,\text{cm/s})(323.2\text{ cm}^{-1})
      = 6.42\times10^{-21}\,\text{J}.
\]

Thus

\[
T=\frac{h\nu}{k_{\text{B}}x}
  = \frac{6.42\times10^{-21}\,\text{J}}
         {(1.380649\times10^{-23}\,\text{J/K})(0.0986)}
  \approx 4.7\times10^{3}\text{ K}.
\]

\[
\boxed{4.7\times10^{3}} \text{ K}
\]
llm_output:

Using the perfect gas equation
Calculate the pressure in kilopascals exerted by $1.25 \mathrm{~g}$ of nitrogen gas in a flask of volume $250 \mathrm{~cm}^3$ at $20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
Using the ideal gas equation \(PV=nRT\):

\[
n=\frac{m}{M}=\frac{1.25\ \text{g}}{28.0\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}=0.0446\ \text{mol}
\]

Volume in cubic metres:

\[
V=250\ \text{cm}^3 = 250\times10^{-6}\ \text{m}^3 = 2.5\times10^{-4}\ \text{m}^3
\]

Temperature in kelvin:

\[
T=20^{\circ}\text{C}=293.15\ \text{K}
\]

Ideal‑gas constant:

\[
R=8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}=8.314\ \text{Pa m}^{3}\text{mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
\]

Now

\[
P=\frac{nRT}{V}=\frac{0.0446\times 8.314\times 293.15}{2.5\times10^{-4}}
=4.351\times10^{5}\ \text{Pa}
\]

Convert to kilopascals:

\[
P = \frac{4.351\times10^{5}\ \text{Pa}}{10^{3}} = 435\ \text{kPa}
\]

\[
\boxed{435}\ \text{kPa}
\]

question: When an electric discharge is passed through gaseous hydrogen, the $\mathrm{H}_2$ molecules are dissociated and energetically excited $\mathrm{H}$ atoms are produced. If the electron in an excited $\mathrm{H}$ atom makes a transition from $n=2$ to $n=1$, calculate the wavenumber of the corresponding line in the emission spectrum.
llm_answer:
The wavenumber (frequency in units of inverse centimeters) for the \(n=2 \rightarrow n=1\) transition is given by the Rydberg formula

\[
\tilde\nu = R_{\mathrm H}\!\left(\frac{1}{1^2}-\frac{1}{2^2}\right)=\frac{3}{4}\,R_{\mathrm H}.
\]

With the Rydberg constant for hydrogen \(R_{\mathrm H}=109\,737.3\;\text{cm}^{-1}\),

\[
\tilde\nu=\frac{3}{4}\times 109\,737.3
          = 82\,302.975\;\text{cm}^{-1}\approx 8.23\times10^{4}\;\text{cm}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{82303}\ \text{cm}^{-1}
\]

question: Calculate the energy of one mole of UV photons of wavelength $300 \mathrm{~nm}$ and compare it with a typical single-bond energy of $400 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}$.
llm_answer:
The energy of one photon of wavelength \(300\;\text{nm}\) is  

\[
E_{\text{photon}}=\frac{hc}{\lambda}
   =\frac{(6.626\times10^{-34}\,\text{J·s})(2.998\times10^{8}\,\text{m/s})}{300\times10^{-9}\,\text{m}}
   \approx 6.6\times10^{-19}\,\text{J}.
\]

For one mole of such photons, multiply by Avogadro’s number \(N_A=6.022\times10^{23}\ \text{mol}^{-1}\):

\[
E_{\text{mol}} = N_A\,E_{\text{photon}}
                \approx (6.022\times10^{23})(6.6\times10^{-19}\,\text{J})
                \approx 4.0\times10^{5}\,\text{J\,mol}^{-1}
                = 4.0\times10^{2}\,\text{kJ\,mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{400}\;\text{kJ/mol}
\]

This value is essentially the same magnitude as a typical single‑bond energy of about \(400\;\text{kJ/mol}\).

The ${ }^7 \mathrm{Li}^1 \mathrm{H}$ ground electronic state has $D_0=2.4287 \mathrm{eV}, \nu_e / c=1405.65 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$, and $\nu_e x_e / c=23.20 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$, where $c$ is the speed of light. (These last two quantities are usually designated $\omega_e$ and $\omega_e x_e$ in the literature.) Calculate $D_e$ for ${ }^7 \mathrm{Li}^1 \mathrm{H}$.
llm_answer:
The dissociation energy \(D_e\) is related to the dissociation energy from the \(v=0\) level \(D_0\) by adding the zero‑point vibrational energy (ZPE):

\[
D_e = D_0 + \text{ZPE},\qquad 
\text{ZPE}=G(0)=\frac{\omega_e}{2}-\frac{\omega_e x_e}{4}.
\]

Given  

\[
\omega_e = 1405.65~\text{cm}^{-1}, \qquad \omega_e x_e = 23.20~\text{cm}^{-1},
\]

\[
\text{ZPE}= \frac{1405.65}{2}-\frac{23.20}{4}
          = 702.825-5.800
          = 697.025~\text{cm}^{-1}.
\]

Convert to eV using  

\[
1~\text{eV}=8065.54~\text{cm}^{-1}\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\text{ZPE}\,( \text{eV})= \frac{697.025}{8065.54}=0.0863~\text{eV}.
\]

Finally,

\[
D_e = D_0 + \text{ZPE}= 2.4287~\text{eV}+0.0863~\text{eV}
     \approx 2.515~\text{eV}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.515}\ \text{eV}
\]

question: The positron has charge $+e$ and mass equal to the electron mass. Calculate in electronvolts the ground-state energy of positronium-an "atom" that consists of a positron and an electron.
llm_answer:
The hydrogen atom ground‑state energy is $E_{1}^{(\mathrm{H})}= -13.6\,\mathrm{eV}$, which can be written as  

\[
E_{1}^{(\mathrm{H})} = -\,\frac{\mu c^{2}\alpha^{2}}{2},
\]

where $\mu$ is the reduced mass.  
For positronium, the reduced mass is  

\[
\mu_{\text{Ps}}=\frac{m_{e}\,m_{e}}{m_{e}+m_{e}}=\frac{m_{e}}{2}.
\]

Thus  

\[
E_{1}^{(\text{Ps})}
 = -\,\frac{\mu_{\text{Ps}}}{m_{e}}\,
    \frac{\mu_{\text{H}}c^{2}\alpha^{2}}{2}
 = -\,\frac{\mu_{\text{Ps}}}{m_{e}}\,
    13.6\,\text{eV}
 = -\,\frac12\,13.6\,\text{eV}
 = -\,6.80\,\text{eV}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-6.80}\,\mathrm{eV}
\]

question: Calculate the ratio of the electrical and gravitational forces between a proton and an electron.

An electron in a three-dimensional rectangular box with dimensions of $5.00 Å, 3.00 Å$, and $6.00 Å$ makes a radiative transition from the lowest-lying excited state to the ground state. Calculate the frequency of the photon emitted.
llm_answer:
The energy of a particle in a three‑dimensional infinite square well is  

\[
E_{n_x,n_y,n_z}= \frac{h^{2}}{8m}\!\left(\frac{n_x^{2}}{L_x^{2}}+\frac{n_y^{2}}{L_y^{2}}+\frac{n_z^{2}}{L_z^{2}}\right).
\]

**Ground state** \((n_x,n_y,n_z)=(1,1,1)\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
E_{1,1,1}&=\frac{h^{2}}{8m}\left(\frac{1}{L_x^{2}}+\frac{1}{L_y^{2}}+\frac{1}{L_z^{2}}\right)   \\
&=\frac{(6.62607\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\,s})^{2}}{8(9.10938\times10^{-31}\,\mathrm{kg})}
  \left(\frac{1}{(5.00\times10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m})^{2}}
  +\frac{1}{(3.00\times10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m})^{2}}
  +\frac{1}{(6.00\times10^{-10}\,\mathrm{m})^{2}}\right) \\
&=1.077\times10^{-18}\,\mathrm{J}.
\end{aligned}
\]

**Lowest excited state**

The lowest‑energy excited state is obtained by raising the smallest quantum number that gives the smallest increase in energy.  
Because the well is longest in the \(z\)-direction, the energy spacing for \(n_z\) is smallest:

\[
(n_x,n_y,n_z)=(1,1,2)
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
E_{1,1,2}&=\frac{h^{2}}{8m}\left(\frac{1}{L_x^{2}}
     +\frac{1}{L_y^{2}}+\frac{4}{L_z^{2}}\right)  \\
&=1.579\times10^{-18}\,\mathrm{J}.
\end{aligned}
\]

**Energy difference**

\[
\Delta E =E_{1,1,2}-E_{1,1,1}= (1.579-1.077)\times10^{-18}
          =5.02\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J}.
\]

**Photon frequency**

\[
\nu=\frac{\Delta E}{h}
    =\frac{5.02\times10^{-19}\,\mathrm{J}}{6.62607\times10^{-34}\,\mathrm{J\,s}}
    =7.57\times10^{14}\,\mathrm{s^{-1}}.
\]

\[
\boxed{7.57} \ 10^{14}\,\text{s}^{-1}
\]

The vibrational temperature for the mode is  

\[
\theta=\frac{hc}{k}\tilde{v}=1.4388\ \text{K cm}\times 900\ \text{cm}^{-1}=1.295\times10^{3}\ \text{K}.
\]

At \(T=298\ \text{K}\),

\[
e^{\theta/T}=e^{1295/298}\approx e^{4.34}\approx 77.3, \qquad
e^{\theta/T}-1\approx 76.3 .
\]

The contribution to the molar internal energy per mole of this single mode is  

\[
U_{\mathrm{m},\mathrm{vib}} = R\,
\frac{\theta}{e^{\theta/T}-1}
   = (8.314\ \mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}K^{-1}})
      \frac{1295\ \mathrm{K}}{76.3}
   \approx 1.41\times10^{2}\ \mathrm{J\,mol^{-1}}
   = 0.141\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}} .
\]

\[
\boxed{0.141}\ \mathrm{kJ}\!/\mathrm{mol}
\]

question: In this example, $2.50 \mathrm{~mol}$ of an ideal gas with $C_{V, m}=12.47 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}$ is expanded adiabatically against a constant external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial temperature and pressure of the gas are $325 \mathrm{~K}$ and $2.50 \mathrm{bar}$, respectively. The final pressure is 1.25 bar. Calculate the final $ \Delta U$.
llm_answer:
\[
\Delta U = nC_{V,m}\,\Delta T
          = 2.50\,(12.47)\,(T_f-325)\;\text{J}
\]

Using the first‑law for an adiabatic, irreversible expansion against a constant external pressure  

\[
\Delta U = -P_{\text{ext}}\,(V_f-V_i).
\]

With \(V=\dfrac{nRT}{P}\) and \(P_{\text{ext}}=1.00\;\text{bar}\) ( \(=1.00\times10^{5}\text{ Pa}\) ),
solving the two equations yields  

\[
T_f \approx 2.69\times 10^{2}\ \text{K}\quad\Rightarrow\quad
\Delta T \approx -56.3\ \text{K}
\]

and consequently  

\[
\Delta U \approx 2.50\,(12.47)\,(-56.3)\;\text{J}
          \approx -1.75\times10^{3}\ \text{J}
          = \boxed{-1.75}\ \text{kJ}.
\]

question: The X-band (9.5 GHz) EPR spectrum of a matrix isolated Na atom reveals four hyperfine lines with resonant field positions of 3074 G, 3174 G, 3274 G and 3374 G. Calculate the g value of the atom.
llm_answer:
The resonance condition for an electron spin \(S=\tfrac12\) subject to a magnetic field \(B\) is  

\[
h\nu = g\mu_B B_{\text{res}},
\]

where \(\nu = 9.5\,\text{GHz}\).

The four hyperfine lines arise from the four possible nuclear‑spin projections of \({}^{23}\text{Na}\) \((I=\tfrac32)\).  
The Zeeman field that would be observed if the hyperfine coupling were zero (\(B_0\)) is the mean of the four measured resonance fields:

\[
B_{0}=\frac{3074+3174+3274+3374}{4} \ \text{G} = 3224 \ \text{G}.
\]

Convert this to tesla:

\[
B_{0}=3224\;{\rm G}\times 10^{-4}\;{\rm T/G}=0.3224\;{\rm T}.
\]

Insert the values into \(g=h\nu/(\mu_B B_0)\).  
With \(h=6.626\times10^{-34}\,\text{J\,s}\), \(\mu_B=9.274\times10^{-24}\,\text{J/T}\), and \(\nu=9.5\times10^{9}\,\text{Hz}\):

\[
g=\frac{(6.626\times10^{-34})(9.5\times10^{9})}
          {(9.274\times10^{-24})(0.3224)}
  \approx 2.10.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.10}
\]

\[
L=\sqrt{I(I+1)}\,\hbar ,\qquad I=\frac72 ,

\[
I(I+1)=\frac72\cdot\frac92=\frac{63}{4}=15.75,

\[
L = 3.969\,\hbar\approx3.969\,(1.0545718\times10^{-34}\;\text{J\,s})
     \approx4.19\times10^{-34}\;\text{J\,s}.

\]

\[
P=\frac{\Delta N}{N}\simeq\frac{\Delta E}{2k_B T},
\qquad  
\Delta E=\gamma\hbar B .
\]

Hence

\[
P=\frac{\gamma\hbar B}{2k_B T}

\gamma=2\pi(10.705\times10^6)=6.728\times10^{7}\ \text{rad s}^{-1}\text{T}^{-1},
\]

\[
\hbar = 1.0545718\times10^{-34}\ \text{J s},
\quad
k_B = 1.380649\times10^{-23}\ \text{J K}^{-1},
\quad
T   = 298\ \text{K},
\quad
P   = 2.5\times10^{-6}.
\]

\[
k_BT = (1.380649\times10^{-23})(298)=4.115376\times10^{-21}\ \text{J},
\]
\[
2k_BT\,P = 2(4.115376\times10^{-21})(2.5\times10^{-6})
           = 2.057688\times10^{-26}\ \text{J},
\]
\[
\gamma\hbar = (6.728\times10^{7})(1.0545718\times10^{-34})
             = 7.09203\times10^{-27}\ \text{J T}^{-1}.
\]

\[
B = \frac{2.057688\times10^{-26}}{7.09203\times10^{-27}}

\]

\]

Calculate the equilibrium polarization of 13C nuclei in a 20.0 T magnetic field at 300 K.
llm_answer:
For a spin‑½ nucleus the equilibrium polarization follows from the Boltzmann distribution:

\[
P=\tanh\!\left(\frac{\gamma\hbar B}{2k_{\mathrm B}T}\right)
      \approx\frac{\gamma\hbar B}{2k_{\mathrm B}T}\qquad\bigl(\gamma\hbar B\ll k_{\mathrm B}T\bigr)
\]

where  

* \(\gamma_{^{13}\mathrm C}=6.729\times10^{7}\,\text{rad\,s}^{-1}\text{T}^{-1}\) (gyromagnetic ratio),  
* \(\hbar =1.055\times10^{-34}\,\text{J\,s}\),  
* \(k_{\mathrm B}=1.381\times10^{-23}\,\text{J\,K}^{-1}\),  
* \(B=20.0\,\text{T}\),  
* \(T=300\,\text{K}\).

Calculation:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\gamma\hbar B &= (6.729\times10^{7})(1.055\times10^{-34})(20.0)\\
              &= 1.42\times10^{-25}\,\text{J},\\[4pt]
2k_{\mathrm B}T &= 2(1.381\times10^{-23})(300)\\
                &= 8.28\times10^{-21}\,\text{J}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus

\[
P \approx \frac{1.42\times10^{-25}}{8.28\times10^{-21}}
   = 1.7\times10^{-5}\; .
\]

\[
\boxed{1.7\times10^{-5}}
\]
